comments.commentBody: This is all so completely depressing -- that Trump and Cruz are serious candidates, that they don't need to discuss issues, that we are already spending so much time discussing them, and that one of them could actually win.

Trump can't raise money from anyone but himself and has no noticeable group of insiders who coach, counsel, and advise him. He takes advice from himself.

Cruz can't get anybody in politics or who's ever worked with him to like him, and after the mess with the loans appears to lack integrity. Those are the two Republican candidates who, for now, lead. Ben Carson, who bolted out of the gate, is fading at the top of the stretch and his campaign is gasping for air, a gasp sometimes mistaken for a death rattle.

Can any of these outsiders really be the person who Republicans voters want to represent them at the top of the Presidential ticket? There are some things that are immutable in politics if a candidate wants to get elected: can the candidate raise money; can the candidate get the support of the establishment who will contribute their own influence and organizations in the campaign; is the candidate likable just enough not to have voters look away before listening to them; do they have the kind of organization that's been tested by fire to bring voters to the polls on election day.

If any of these outsiders expects to win the Presidency, the established political organizations, donors, and workers are going to have to be on board. Period. As unhappy as voters say they are with the order of things now, without the establishment, who the GOP frontrunners seem to distain, they are toast in a general election. Quoting George Zimmer, I guarantee it.

Even before becoming King Of All Media Trump had a distinct advantage. His opposition is a field of midgets. Even Cruz only qualifies as a tall midget, a one term senator from Texas without a friend to his name.

The Republicans were so stimulated by the thought of running against Hillary Clinton everyone and their dog filed for primaries. The result was a diffusion equal to pouring a quart of water into a shot of whiskey. Only Trump had the profile and inherent street smarts to bolt out of the gate and not look back.

The GOP is dead in the water and deservedly so.Their Great White Hope in Orange Mane and suit crafted in a slave factory in China bearing his own name will fail miserably 10 minutes after the first debate starts and his hot air is shown for what it is. The country will either be saved by Bernie or will be destroyed in a class warfare brought on by the destruction of the economy due to Wall street managers 'RE ENGINEERING " companies fro  greater profits for the CEO PAYCHECKS.

Just listen to Marco Rubio and Chris Christie. Are they really more unacceptable than Donald Trump or Ted Cruz? If so, by no more than a whisker. Meanwhile, poor, sad Jeb! strays so far from the exclamation point following his name that he appears to be wandering, perpetually lost, eyeglasses askew, in a very dense fog of inconsequence.

www.endthemadnessnow.org

Maybe these voters are finally recognizing, at least subliminally, that the mainstream candidates haven't really been representing them (c.f. What's the Matter With Kansas), and are casting about desperately for someone outside the establishment.
Hey Expat, I know this is a bit of a pedantic quibble, but it was Stalin, not Lenin, who had Trotsky killed.

I am aDemocrat in Kentucky. I won't be affecting anything until in May. Just a brief observation on reporting and talking heads on TV, please find another word or grouping for those you all refer to as "less educated." I have two degrees and I don't t put myself in that group but having said that I know from my studies what a struggle and then a joy a lot of folks have and had the first time they got to vote and keeping on voting. It's about respect for all of us.   John

replies.commentBody: Obviously I meant "didn't" regarding the GOP's (r)ejection of Trump.

comments.commentBody:
Yes, Nate, Mr. Trump *is* a "true celebrity," every bit as much as are Kim Kardashian and Paris Hilton. All three are rich, famous, over exposed and no more qualified to be President than is an eighth-grader, whose vocabulary they each employ.

Post-election, it will be to the then-dead Republican Party's undying regret it did forcibly eject Trump at the outset of his campaign-cum-Don Rickles act. Without Trump, Cruz would be second-tier, battling with Carly Fiorina to hang on to next-to-last place. Trump made Cruz, now regrets it, and created a whole new problem for the terminally afflicted GOP in the bargain.

replies.commentBody:
In Ted Cruz at least, it seems this is what the base has been wanting for a long time. They're always crying that if only they could get a "Real Conservative," (ie. not Romney, McCain, Bushes), they could show America how awesome their ideas are and lead us forward in truth, until Jesus comes back to take over America. Or... whatever...

I hope they get their man this time, too, so that in the general we can remove this fantasy from their heads for another decade or two. The fringes serve a purpose but they are small tents and the rest of America won't fit in there.

comments.commentBody:
The utter absurdity of the GOP Establishment being held hostage to a battle between Donald Trump and Ted Cruz reminded me of that 1978 comedic masterpiece "Animal House", with Jeb Bush playing the role of "Robert Hoover", the hapless president of the Delta Tau Chi fraternity, caught in a war between John Belushi's Donald Trump-like "Bluto Blutarsky" and James Daughton's character "Greg Mamalard", to whom Ted Cruz bears more than passing resemblance. In a grudge match to the death, Hoover's character becomes collateral damage from the get go.

Donald Trump has been taunting the Republican Establishment by threatening to run for president since 2008, when he tried to turn then-Sen. Barack Obama's fatherless childhood into an elaborate treasure hunt, looking for proof that Obama was really born in Kenya, despite public records proving without a doubt that he was born in Hawaii.

Trump has an unerring instinct for the jugular, and he has a preternatural skill for detecting any sort of weakness in an opponent. Jeb Bush, and by extension the party's Establishment wing, fell victim to Trump's onslaught of insults and insinuations largely because he is unsuited to the vitriol and hyperbole that Trump and Cruz engage in for sport. This is a bearbaiting contest in which elaborate policy papers have no place.

The party establishment, almost to a man, wants to put forward a gentlemanly candidate with impeccable conservative credentials and excellent manners. That is not going to happen.

replies.commentBody: Ryan's beard reminded me of a tradition in a local school for 3rs-5th graders, "mustache day", a proud, gender free event that is hilarious. But then that fits his overall profile as someone who fell in love with Ayn Rand as a young person and just can't give her up now that he's in his forties.

Ryan's political career is an example of being promoted to the highest level of incompetence. If Ryan wins the nomination in a brokered convention, the GOP should rename a lane for the Peter Principle candidate.

comments.commentBody:
Extremists historically eat their own: Lenin had Trotsky killed, Islamic factions terrorize each other, even the gun nus fight amongst themselves.

A brokered convention will turn to Ryan, and he knows that because, thank God, he shaved off that ridiculous beard.
Ironic that recent court opinions on campaign financing has diminished party control of the candidate selection.

Maybe, just maybe, the Republican establishment wants to lose the coming election to prove a point that the RNC's 2013 analysis of the party made very clear. Conservatives talking to conservatives is not going to win presidential elections. And the demographics of metropolitan areas, where 80 percent of citizens live, are not in their favor.

So what happens? The majority of candidates are so far to the right of a moderate center-right position that none of them can be elected in November. And that's perhaps just fine with the party leadership, which understands that losing elections is the only thing that may force the party back toward the center, where democracy works and elections are won.

As for Sarah Palin, she is indicative of just how pathetic and clueless the low-information segment of the voting public is. She's incoherent, a babbler of nonsense and without any apparent functional insights regarding reality. My impression is that even Trump doesn't want to be associated with her in any obvious way.

Eclectic Pragmatist — http://eclectic-pragmatist.tumblr.com/
Eclectic Pragmatist — https://medium.com/eclectic-pragmatism

replies.commentBody:
If either Trump or Cruz goes to Cleveland with a clear lead in delegates, but not enough to clinch the nomination, and if the Republican establishment cuts enough deals to "steal" the nomination from either of them in favor of someone else, then the following will happen:

1. Either (a) Trump/Cruz (whichever winds up getting "shafted" at the convention) will run third-party or (b) the supporters of Trump/Cruz will sit out the general election or will write in their candidate; and
2. Whether it's 1(a) or 1(b), the Republican nominee will lose in November.

I think that the Republican establishment is smart enough to realize this. That's why, depending on the delegate count going into the convention, they may decide to swallow hard and fall in line with Trump or Cruz as their nominee, on the theory that if united (even if only on the surface) they have a chance, whereas if divided they clearly have no chance.

I thought that they were already falling in line with Trump -- some of them -- as Cruz was so despised. Yet, his pockets seem well stuffed.

I still am incredulous that the party establishment believed that Jeb! was their man.

comments.commentBody:
I wonder what the odds in Vegas are for a brokered Republican Convention?

I am not a Republican, but seem to remember that delegates are only pledged for the first ballot- after that they are free to vote for anybody they choose. Remember, delegates select the nominee- not voters. When you vote during Primary season you are electing delegates- not candidates.

The name I hear being bandied around is Paul Ryan- yes THAT Paul Ryan. Having punched his ticket as VP Nominee last time and as Speaker now, the young Congressman will be presented as qualified and the good little Republicans will get in line. Ryan and John Kasich. No Republican has ever won the Presidency without Ohio.

So many of these comments are smart and detailed, but I question one of the common themes. People keep saying that blue-collar Republicans (and crossover Democrats) have been taught FEAR by their chosen media reps and by the most combative candidates. But,  in my opinion, the Republican Party is currently in deep trouble  because Fox News and its allies have taught many citizens which groups (and presidents) they can freely HATE. I think Fox and friends,  including most of the current Republican candidates, have been committed to preaching and teaching good ole' masculine hatred (not feminine fear). It's always reassuring, even comforting,  to join a team and attack the opposition. I, a liberal, am newly inspired with hot hatred of Sarah Palin (since she blamed Obama for her son's assault on his girlfriend). It's the season. That said, the loathsome, cocky, xenophobic, tribal messages preached by Trump and Cruz (Ted, who shared the stage with a pastor calling for the execution of all gay U.S. citizens) are so mean and crude and empty they're incredible ... meaning "not credible." Can't believe it. Nobody could create these characters, these candidates, in a believable novel. Editors would laugh you out of the office. So they must be real. Oh. That scares me.
That these two men will actually be on the ballot is inconceivable.

I worry about articles like these they're much like a football team who's points are solid on the board, hence they relax. What happens during half time, the other team re-creates determination and low behold we have 2012 all over again. So beware we have to make 2016 count in all places.
Not to worry Establishment GOP. Your candidate still holds a slight lead in the Democratic primary race.

Chickens, roost, etc.

Well-deserved.
It looks to me that the Bush campaign is more interested in simply beating Candidate Rubio than anything else.

This has become a pillow fight between blowhards who offer the voters nothing meaningful. At least Kasich managed a mention.

The losers are the American voters who even remotely think the Republican Party has offered them worthy candidates.

Unfortunately it is too late for a brand new slate.

replies.commentBody:
You could say the same thing about Debbie Wasserman-Schultz & the Democratic Establishment. The former Vice Chair of Hillary 2008 is the DNC Chair & did everything she could to grease the skids for Hillary including hiding & limiting debates- Obama steadily gained ground on her through the 2008 cycle on the televised debates.

The Establishment within the professional left- The AFT, NEA, Planned Parenthood, NARAL & HRC all endorsed Hillary without a full vote of membership. This despite Bernie Sanders' long time open support of women's rights, GLBTQ rights and worker's rights to join unions. Hillary was defending DOMA in 2008.

Unlike Hillary, Bernie's endorsers did so on the basis of fully polling membership. MoveOn, Democracy for America, the Communications Workers of America & National Nurses United all held votes open to the full membership before endorsing Bernie. But that is grass roots versus Clinton astroturf. I cannot wait until NARAL, HRC and Planned Parenthood send me a letter/e-mail asking for funds or whatever- they can go pound sand.

Hillary's people think they can steal the nomination and then shame Progressives into voting for her or else the bad Republican wolf will appoint more Conservative Judges. That is not going to happen- the court is lost with 5 Hard Right Republicans on it that will all have to be carried out in a box before they give up their seat.

I- like millions of others- am an independent Progressive and owe Hillary and the DNC nothing.

comments.commentBody:
The Republican establishment wanted Jeb Bush so much they kind of rigged the process for him, with the "moderate" blue states being winner-take-all after the "conservative" mostly Southern states were proportional. It backfired but the odd thing is that they thought GOP voters would accept Jeb Bush if they had another real choice. They didn't have that choice until Trump got in but as soon as he did, Bush started collapsing.

Bush has behaved like an entitled, petulant, arrogant whiner. His brother hasn't dared show his face at 2 GOP conventions in a row. The establishment picked a terrible candidate.

The Republican Party bought this on itself by it's determined campaign to make "liberal" into a term so vile that people would do just about anything to avoid it. They embraced and venerated vicious talk radio hosts - and really, Donald Trump and Ted Cruz are only aping the tirades and vitriol of Limbaugh , Hannity, Ingraham, and Beck. Now I hear "conservatives" trying to convince themselves of  glaring falsehoods, such as "Mr. Trump is a firm Christian with good morals!" and "Trump believes in personal responsibility!" (for you maybe; he is quite happy to use bankruptcy laws to ditch his own obligations) and "Ted Cruz is trustworthy!" All because they don't want to be called "liberals".

replies.commentBody: I fear that Cruz could beat Bernie.

comments.commentBody: Cruz cannot beat Hilary or Bernie. Gold Bless the USA

Who's more Establishment than the New York Times? You don't get it because people are fed up with getting the shaft and they blame elites in general. I predict a very disturbing and undignified election season.
